On 25 March 2011 12:51, Drew Kirkpatrick <drew.kirkpatrick@...> wrote=
:
>
> Just curious as I've been thinking about this a bit lately (I'm new t=
o NEAT stuff), as it
> seems that the micro mutations you talk about, if I'=
m=A0interpreting=A0papers right, is one of
> the reasons standard NEAT does=
n't handle fractured domain problems well. As you
> say, it can't "get ther=
e from here". It can't build enough structure and optimize it's
> performan=
ce to find a better solution before that species dies out.

Actually "fract=
ured domains" wasn't a term I was aware of, however I
just read this:

   E=
volving Neural Networks for Fractured Domains (2008), Nate Kohl
and Risto M=
iikkulainen.
   http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/downloads/papers/kohl.gecco08.pdf

=
So fractured domains =3D discontinuity. And yes I would say that's
definite=
ly a major problem with NEAT (not sure about HyperNEAT). I'm
interested in =
their use of radial basis functions, which is something
that has been menti=
oned before on this group but not something that
I've looked into deeply.

=
> Is this the problem you're looking to address here? Or just a method of e=
scaping a local
> maxima in fitness by allowing more radical adjustments/gr=
owth to network topologies in
> general?

Well it's essentially the same th=
ing if discontinuity is the reason
you're stuck - which is very often the c=
ase I would say. Complex
fitness lanscapes are almsot by definition 'fractu=
red' (As an exercise
try and think up a complex landscape/domain that isnlt=
 fractured).

> One thing I was wondering about, and I haven't poked around=
 to see if anyone has done
> some research into, is fiddling with the speci=
es die-off parameter. I was thinking it might
> be worth trying (if someone=
 hasn't done it yet), is to remove the species die off if-hasn't-
> improve=
d-in X generations bit if no species fitness has improved in some specified=

> amount of generations.

I wouldn't expect this to be a major issue where=
 we are right now. If
a species hasn't improved in a long time then it's pr=
obability of
improving in a further equally long time is low. Evolutionary
=
techniques constarined by computing resources are always a
probabilities ga=
me - you try and spend your limited CPU time searching
the areas of the spa=
ce that have the highest probabilities of yielding
good solutions. This sam=
e argument sort of applies to the idea of
increasing populations - from one=
 perspective the size of the
population is irrelevant as you can only evalu=
ate some fixed number of
genomes per unit of time. The main effect of pop s=
ize is thus to
provide a broader genetic base to drive genetic crossover an=
d to keep
an as diverse as possible population of search points across the
=
fitness landscape.


> I think if you've sat with the same "champion" for a=
 large number of generations, it could
> be worthwhile to do something radi=
cal, like greatly increase mutations,

Agreed. Just generally - if a search=
 is stuck then 'do something else'
would seem to be good advice :)


> I'm =
sure someone has toyed with this at some point. I can always use another co=
uple
> hundred of pages of papers/dissertations to add to my "to-be-read" p=
ile going into my
> thesis :)


I think others have played with dynamic mut=
ation rate. The problem I
think is that there may not be any easy routes ou=
t of a local maxima,
increasing mutations will sample points a little furth=
er out than
before but it's potentially clutching at straws in many cases. =
The
other way of looking at it is that the encoding space or the fitness
la=
ndscape (sort of teh same thing) could be changed such that there
are easie=
r routes to the good solutions - that's essentially what the
radial basis f=
unction paper above is doing - your nets can;' get there
from here, so use =
a different type of net.

Colin
